Typically the problem description leads into making it clear why we need a new design. That doesn't seem to be the case here. This says OpenBMC is missing some RAS functions - how does that imply a pHAL? Missing RAS function would require a lot of other function as well. So I wonder if the problem description should be more specific.

+1, Yes . bringing in RAS in this document makes the expectation out of pHAL to balloon up

Main goal of pHAL is to enable Host side RAS as i mentioned here. pHAL providing better host RAS capability by add additional infrastructure like maintaining  Host atributes and providing infrastructre support for Dump and PRD application. Iwould have rephrase this to RAS to Host RAS.
Should we include buses as well (Intra processor bus) or may be end with full stop with Host processors, memory subsystem, etc.

In all of the above cases, will there be some sort of secure mode to prevent the BMC from modifying registers/memory?

If SBE is not available , system is going to be in termination state ( single BMC systems).
lab/Debug mode , already have mechanism to support native scoms for SBE debug

This problem description is in the abstract. I think you need to tie it to concrete gaps in OpenBMC's current capabilities. You might need to also frame it in terms of concrete requirements for enterprise systems to expose why work is required for OpenBMC.
This should be a bullet list. Currently it's hard to parse due to word-wrap, and even just the '*' to delineate a new entry would help with readability.
This should probably point to devicetree.org
This code is _specifically_ platform dependent. The "platform independent" bit is e.g. FAPI and the surrounding runtime infra (as in, the hardware team don't have to care how that works).
This doesn't expand what "libfdt" actually is. This needs to say "The flattened devicetree library" somewhere.
So should it be called the "Power" HAL? This seems to suggest x86 could use it. Have you consulted anyone from e.g. Intel or ARM? Or should this sentence be removed/reformulated?
This paragraph feels like a rerun of earlier information in the background section. I'd remove it.
Why the underscore in the link text?

I think this is a misuse of the impact section. What impact does the design have on the OpenBMC project? Is it duplicating work that other platform designers have done? Are there opportunities to work with other platforms and architectures to pick out pieces that are generally useful rather than developing something POWER specific?
This section should be a statement of intent, not a handwave about what's possible. What concrete approaches are you planning to take to test all this code, both at a unit and integration level?
